What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback

Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 8-10 hours
5-7 hours
10-15, depending upon homework difficulty. Sometime much less, sometimes much more.
I spent at least 10 hrs/week on this course.

Spent a great amount of time each week on the homework. Would have been better to have a primer over winter break before the course started to be introduced to Python. It was a very difficult program to learn throughout the semester.
5h

Lack of clarity in the rubric and expectations for homework and assignments.
Professor would update his requirements randomly after assignment and would not make an announcement. The TA would tell something different to people in office hours and made the overall situation very confusing on what the expectations are.

The course was structured well and I feel like I gained some useful technical skills.  I think that the course could be strengthened by having more assigned reading before lecture so that the materials isn't completely new during lecture.
Awesome course- obviously very challenging but I really felt like I learned so much from this class, and gained real-world skills that will make me competitive in future job markets.

The class covers pretty interesting information and seems like a good follow up to Cost Effectiveness.

The class is a lot of work. Furthermore, it uses Python (which could be a good thing for us to learn new skills) but there is just simply not enough teaching on this for us to write our own code for the homework. The homework also take an incredibly large amount of time and becomes more of a struggle to find the correct code than actually applying the concepts learned in class. The class also has only 1 TF which does not seem like enough. The office hours are too crowded to ask for enough help and the homework isn't graded on a timely basis or with enough detail to show us what we did wrong. It seems that this course would benefit more from a lab than a 2 hour session every week (which is not enough).

the topics are interesting but there isn't enough support for the python code. Completing the homework doesn't allow me to fully understand Python. I think this course should have a lab section where the code is explained in a more detailed way. And start simple. To be honest, I'd rather have more class time but more thorough teaching on the topics. Right now it feels we are touching briefly on both the model and the code. I'd rather have fewer topics but a deeper understanding of those we do cover in the class.
It is not suitable for students without strong statistical background or Python experience. Maybe this course can try to be more accessible.

Strengths: Material and skills gained actually feel useful; homeworks felt designed to push students to think critically about skills taught in class rather than just regurgitating ideas; Final project provides an excellent opportunity to further apply skills and develop a project for job/internship applications.

Weaknesses: Homework instructions were not always clear but assignments were graded harshly (e.g., instructions may not mention certain output requirements, grades sometimes based on output from specific seeds); Students have no way to implement homework feedback (see below); final project presentations rushed.

In the future, I would recommend offering students the opportunity to resubmit homeworks for a slight bump in grade. This would require delaying posting answers for, say, a week, which may not be suitable in the professor's opinion. I would also recommend removing discrete-event simulation models or at least offering that homework as an optional assignment during the break--it would have been much more useful to have had a homework on sensitivity analysis, for example. Finally, I would recommend stretching the final presentation schedule out to two days or maybe promoting students to work together so as to reduce the number of presentations.

This course was challenging and taught me a lot. I believe that students would have benefited from an additional TF, as Savanah (who was great!) seemed overwhelmed at times and sometimes would not reply to emails. In addition, I would have liked to have been able to download PyCharm and start getting familiar with the syntax of the program prior to the start of the semester. A big barrier for me in this course was understanding Python itself, which at times detracted from the time I had to solidify my understanding of the actual core concepts of the course.

Strengths - amazing subject matter with great potential application to a variety of public health topics and current issues, encourages understanding of Python as a means to accomplish a full project individually as a result of the lessons 
Weaknesses - is not at all an intro level course and should require some additional supplies or requirements, heavy work load that requires TF assistance
Great class, rough in the morning!

This is an excellent course and introduction to more advanced topics in modeling for healthcare decisionmaking and also as an introduction to Python. I think the course strengths are in Reza's lecture notes, in-class labs, and homework assignments to begin to think about the implementation of the various modeling principles.

I wish that there were more opportunities to discuss and review implementation of sensitivity analysis -- basically, I'm saying I wish there was a homework for us to think about the implementation before the final project. HOWEVER, I really appreciate preserving the sanctity of that last week where there is no homework, because the final project takes a long time. Perhaps there may be a way to combine two smaller homework assignments and give another one to discuss implementation of the sensitivity analysis.

Additionally, it would be nice to get a bit more discussion and feedback on implementation on model calibration. I understand that this is a challenging topic, and many students are coming in with different levels of exposure to Bayes theorem; however, I think we were missing a practical discussion on how the model implementation using weights and resampling related to model calibration in the discussion of Bayes theroem.

Lastly, it may be helpful to discuss some of the theory in terms of identifying questions to model. Some of the readings related to this, but it may be nice to have a bit more discussion. It was very challenging to think about how to simplify a system to create a model, and I felt somewhat unprepared in this process. I understand that assumptions and uncertainty is inherent in model-building, but it would be nice to be a little bit more familiar with some of  the theory along with the implementation.

Strengths
Substantially improved python and modelling skills
Comfortable understanding academic publications on modelling and creating simplified models

Weaknesses
May have benefited from a flipped classroom approach
learn multiple models and python
Hard work load, but generally interesting and useful.

This was a quite difficult course, mostly due to the homework assignments. There were a lot of pieces to each assignment, but the rubric was only 3 points. It would be better to have a more descriptive rubric where students can earn partial credit for each homework problem, otherwise there ends up being a lot of panic for very few points. There were many times where I had a code with an error that I could not figure out and did not have timely feedback from the TA, which left me to submit an assignment with errors that then resulted in missed points.
Great for building practical skillset
The course is very helpful for modeling experience but difficult if one is unfamiliar with python programming
This is a coding class. There should be better instructions on coding or a primer before the class
Reza was very effective at translating this complicated material into a structure that could be understood and applied in Python.
Amazing professor! There are few people I could listen to talk about Python and coding at 8 am but he made it really interesting and engaging.

You can tell Reza is very knowledgeable. However, it seems difficult to teach us Python. He is open to students coming to office hours but he didn't seem to have other resources for Python coding except the courses at the beginning (which wasn't enough for me).
Reza is very kind and approachable. No comments.
Reza is wonderful! He is very responsive to emails.
The instructor was great, open to help any student with concepts, homework, etc. Positive attitude and excitement about course content.
Very funny, willing to interact with students and answer questions. Very easy to set up appointments with.

Reza is an excellent lecturer and devoted teacher. His lecture notes serve as an excellent reference to review throughout the course. He teaches a very challenging class and provides students with resources that will enable them to succeed -- he answers questions on Piazza in a timely fashion, he makes time to meet with students outside of class, and he takes care in answering questions in class.
Fantastic prof
Very helpful
Awesome!
Reza is great as an instructor and very helpful in one-on-one meetings. Really enjoyed his class, just prefer to have a better rubric for grading homeworks.
Great at making time to help students outside of class
Very intelligent professor who teaches valuable topics for modeling. Sometime his deeper understanding makes explanation of some topics difficult to a novice in the subject.
I would recommend because of the topics learned

This course teaches a lot of useful information in terms of modeling. However, would not recommend if you have a heavy course load already and are not open to spending a lot of time learning and coding in Python.
Interesting topics but huge workload if you are not a genius with Python, especially because Python feels very different from SAS or R. Experience with SAS or R doesn't indicate success with Python.

This course pairs nicely with Cost-Effectiveness Analysis & Decision Making as it allows you to move from being a consumer of those studies to a producer. If you have interested in modeling I would highly recommend you take this class.
I would recommend this course for any student who knows that they have a vested interest in modeling and who is comfortable with Python syntax.

This course uses Python as a means of simulating policy or program implementations and analyzing outcomes. The coding aspect takes a lot of time and effort but at the end of the semester you are able to produce an entire simulation model with outcomes, comparing policies or treatments, as well as cost-effectiveness analyses and sensitivity analyses. Very tough course but provides a tangible skill that spans multiple realms of public health.

This is an excellent course if you are looking for exposure to programming in Python and an introduction into implementation of healthcare models. I would highly recommend it to other students, and encourage them to protect 5-10 hours a week to complete the homeworks -- they are challenging, but really help you understand the principles and code. I felt comfortable implementing the code for the final project,
Highly recommend if willing to put in the time (and frustration over debugging)
Highly recommend

Learning how to build different mathematical models in Python for a variety of healthcare questions.
I would highly recommend this course to students with the caveat that they have some prior experience with coding.
Difficult course but overall helpful skills for anyone hoping to work I. Any public health modeling field.
